883.question: Do the methods that work best on academic papers also work best on Wikipedia?
883.response: {'Answer': 'The methods that work best on academic papers do not necessarily work best on Wikipedia.'}

884.question: What is their system's absolute accuracy?
884.response: {'Answer': 'The system has an absolute accuracy of 59.07% on Wikipedia, 77.30% on Peer Review, and 79.54% on Blogs.'}
884.answer: 59.4% on wikipedia dataset, 93.4% on peer-reviewed archive AI papers, 77.1%  on peer-reviewed archive Computation and Language papers, and 79.9% on peer-reviewed archive Machine Learning papers

887.question: Which languages do they use?
887.response: {'Answer': 'The confusion matrix of the JOINT model on Wikipedia shows that the model is able to correctly classify most of the articles. The model is able to correctly classify 397 out of 597 FA articles, 299 out of 490 GA articles, 253 out of 353 B articles, 193 out of 332 C articles, 239 out of 362 Start articles, and 345 out of 485 Stub articles.'}

888.question: How large is their data set?
888.response: {'Answer': 'The dataset has 1454 Wikipedia articles, 589 cs.ai articles, 140 PeerReview articles and 122 cs.org articles.'}
888.answer: a sample of  29,794 wikipedia articles and 2,794 arXiv papers
